newsitem.title: UK: Euro bourses fall, hit by weak Wall St.
newsitem.headline: Euro bourses fall, hit by weak Wall St.

text.p: European stocks fell from record levels in early trade on Thursday, dragged down by a sharp overnight sell-off on Wall Street.
On currency markets, the dollar was strong in morning transactions, rising against the mark as new figures showed Germany's unemployment rose to post-World War Two record levels in January.
In London, Europe' biggest bourse, shares slipped 0.27 percent after the FTSE 100 index closed at a record of 4,281.5 on Wednesday on hopes that low interest rates would be sustained.
"It seems that every time we get close to 4,300 the sellers come in," said one trader.
The Dow ended 86 points lower on Wednesday after being up five points as London markets closed. Technology stocks led the sell-off and Nasdaq posted its tenth largest one-day drop.
The Dow's fall occurred despite news that the U.S. central bank's policy-making body had left interest rates unchanged at its two-day meeting that ended on Wednesday.
In Paris, French shares opened sharply lower on the back of the overnight fall on Wall Street. Trading was nervous ahead of important U.S. unemployment data due on Friday.

Cie Gnrale des Eaux and Havas were suspended pending a statement. The two companies will hold a joint news conference starting at 1630 GMT where they are expected to announce a deal concerning their stakes in satellite broadcaster Canal Plus .
The blue-chip CAC-40 index was down nearly 0.5 percent at mid-morning after closing at a record 2,541.25 on Wednesday.
In Frankfurt, stocks slipped in and out of the minus column in early trade but perked up slightly as the higher-than-expected jobless figures were seen as keeping interest rates in check.
On the foreign exchange front, the dollar strengthened as German government figures showed unemployment surged by over a half a million in January to a new post-war record of 4.66 million.
The unemployment rate, which is based on unadjusted data, rose to 12.2 percent, compared with 10.8 percent in December.

"The report is certainly going to keep dollar/mark well bid. Going into the G7, it would look a bit odd if the current weakness of the numbers in Germany and Japan made the G7 able to feel able to do much about the dollar's rise," said Chris Turner, currency strategist at BZW in London.
The dollar was up nearly half a pfennig by mid-morning and was also stronger against the yen.

The jobless data set the tone for a day of strong trading for the dollar, with analysts seeing little reason to sell it off except some profit-taking and perhaps a little wariness ahead of the Group of Seven (G7) meeting in Berlin this weekend.

"Weak unemployment figures...would reinforce speculation of monetary easing in Germany, and that should give the dollar a bit of a bid against the mark," said Nigel Richardson, international economist at Yamaichi International.
CURRENCIES AT 1050 GMT
The dollar was quoted at 1.6505 marks and 123.68 yen compared with 1.6479 marks and 123.54 yen in late European trading on Wednesday.
STOCK MARKETS AT 1030 GMT
LONDON - The FTSE-100 index was 18.0 points down at 4263.5.
FRANKFURT - The 30-share DAX index was 2.59 higher at 3100.59.
PARIS - The CAC-40 was down 11.75 at 2,529.5.
PRECIOUS METALS
Gold was unchanged at the fix at $342.95 an ounce.
